children.text: ) is a 1963 film by famed Senegalese director Ousmane Sembène. With a runtime of about twenty minutes, Sembène’s first ever film recounts the day-in-the-life of an impoverished borom sarret or horse-cart driver who lives in the Medina–the rural and working-class outskirts of Dakar–and provides transportation for people who wish to make the trip to the Plateau, a major formerly colonial administrative center where the elites–both Senegalese and European–live.
